channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Judge Keeps Door Open to Special Master in Trump Documents Inquiry
item.description: The federal judge in Florida also indicated that she would unseal a more detailed inventory of the materials seized in the search of the former president’s Mar-a-Lago home.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Mazzei, Alan Feuer and Charlie Savage
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The appointment of an independent arbiter is unlikely to derail the Justice Department’s inquiry into whether former President Donald J. Trump illegally held onto national security papers at his beachfront property.

item.title: Judge Says Lindsey Graham Can Be Questioned About Election Activity
item.description: Prosecutors in Atlanta have called the Republican senator to testify before a special grand jury investigating efforts by Donald J. Trump and his allies to overturn his election loss.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset
item.media:description: Senator Lindsey Graham made phone calls to Georgia’s Republican secretary of state, Brad Raffensperger, shortly after the November 2020 election.

item.title: Top Lawyer for Oath Keepers Is Arrested in Connection With Jan. 6 Attack
item.description: The lawyer, Kellye SoRelle, was charged with obstructing the certification of the 2020 election and tampering with evidence in the Justice Department’s investigation of the Capitol riot.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Ken Bensinger
item.media:credit: House Select Committee, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Kellye SoRelle in a video released by the House committee investigating the Capitol riot. She is the latest member of the Oath Keepers to be indicted.

item.title: California Approves a Wave of Aggressive New Climate Measures
item.description: After lobbying by the governor, lawmakers adopted $54 billion in climate spending and voted to keep open the state’s last nuclear plant.
item.dc:creator: Brad Plumer
item.media:description: The Route Fire burning alongside Interstate 5 in Castaic, Calif., on Wednesday.

item.title: In California’s Housing Fight, It’s Newsom vs. NIMBY
item.description: Laws to encourage more development and denser housing don’t do much good if no one enforces them. As the state political calculus shifts, Gavin Newsom is trying to change that.
item.dc:creator: Conor Dougherty and Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom, who is running for re-election, is taking an increasingly aggressive stance toward localities that ignore California housing laws.

item.title: Extreme Heat Pummels California as Crews Battle Wildfires
item.description: The heat, which has broken daily records in some places, is also stretching the state’s electricity supplies.
item.dc:creator: Jill Cowan
item.media:description: Fire crews working a wildfire near Dulzura, Calif., on Thursday. California wildfires chewed through rural areas east of San Diego on Thursday, racing through bone-dry brush and prompting evacuations as the state sweltered under a heat wave that could last through Labor Day.

item.title: Updated Booster Shots Expected Within Days as C.D.C. Panel Signs Off
item.description: The debut of Omicron-specific vaccines raises a thorny question: How long should you wait between shots?
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mueller
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodriguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Epidemiologists predicted that having updated booster vaccines by next week, rather than mid-November, could save between 7,500 and 18,000 lives by the spring.

item.title: With Serena Williams on Center Stage, U.S. Open Tries to Draw New Fans
item.description: Here’s how the U.S. Open’s Twitter account described Serena-mania: “SO MUCH CONTENT” (then 31 exclamation points).
item.dc:creator: Jesus Jiménez
item.category: Billie Jean King National Tennis Center
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams waved to fans after beating Anett Kontaveit, the world No. 2, on Wednesday night.

item.title: Rick Scott Lashes Out at Mitch McConnell in Sign of Dimming Republican Hopes for Senate
item.description: Senator Rick Scott appeared to escalate a quarrel with Senator Mitch McConnell, indicating eroding confidence in the party about reclaiming a majority.
item.dc:creator: Annie Karni
item.media:credit: Emil Lippe for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Unfortunately, many of the very people responsible for losing the Senate last cycle are now trying to stop us from winning the majority this time by trash-talking our Republican candidates,” Senator Rick Scott wrote in an opinion piece on Thursday.

item.title: Politics updates: Ginni Thomas emailed Wisconsin lawmakers about 2020.
item.description: In the Mich
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: Virginia Thomas sent form letters to Wisconsin state legislators urging them to overturn the 2020 presidential result.

item.title: Does This Fisherman Have the Right to Be in a Billionaire’s Backyard?
item.description: A fight along Colorado’s waterways pits an alliance of white-water rafters and amateur anglers against some of the nation’s wealthiest landowners, bruising the image of a sportsman’s paradise.
item.dc:creator: Ben Ryder Howe
item.media:credit: Benjamin Rasmussen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Roger Hill, a fly fisherman, in the Arkansas River east of Cotopaxi, Colo. He has sued to have the state clarify its laws around one of his favorite fly-fishing grounds.

item.title: Mississippi Crisis Highlights Climate Threat to Drinking Water Nationwide
item.description: Aging infrastructure and underinvestment have left many cities’ water systems in tatters. Now flooding and other climate shocks are pushing them to failure.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Flavelle, Rick Rojas, Jim Tankersley and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
item.media:description: Catherine Moore waiting for water to boil in Paulette McGee’s home in Jackson, Miss.

item.title: What Critics Are Saying About ‘The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power’
item.description: Amazon’s expensive fantasy saga finally debuts on Thursday night. What do the critics think? Read on.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Vineyard
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)

item.title: ‘The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power’ Is Shiny but Not Yet Precious
item.description: Amazon’s pricey, gorgeous fantasy spectacle delivers what fans expect, but it could thrive by giving them what they don’t.
item.dc:creator: James Poniewozik
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)

item.title: Ken Burns Explores America’s Inaction During the Holocaust
item.description: “The U.S. and the Holocaust,” coming to PBS Sept. 18, examines the reasons behind the country’s inadequate response to Germany’s persecution of Jews.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Berger
item.category: The US and the Holocaust (TV Program)

item.title: A Farewell to Readers
item.description: Binary thinking in politics, race and inequality has distracted us from processing everything else that takes place in the country.
item.dc:creator: Jay Caspian Kang

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Making Citizens
item.description: Public education requires lessons about history and also contact with and context about other Americans: who we are and what has made us.
item.dc:creator: Heather C. McGhee and Victor Ray
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Library of Congress; AlexMSchool, Calsidyrose and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons; and Mika Baumeister and Dima Shishkov, via Unsplash.

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Learning to Read
item.description: All kinds of kids, from all kinds of families — rich, poor and middle class — need more help with reading than they’re getting in school.
item.dc:creator: Emily Hanford
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Carlton Smith, via Library of Congress; Everyday Basics and Drahomír Posteby-Mach, via Unsplash; Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons; and photos-public-domain.com

item.title: Education in America: School Is for Care
item.description: It can be a safe haven for our most vulnerable children.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Grose
item.media:credit: Illustration by Chloe Scheffe; photographs by Internet Archive; Jordan Rowland and the New York Public Library, via Unsplash; and Mikus, via Wikimedia Commons

item.title: America Is Being Consumed by a Moral Panic Over Trans People
item.description: In the run-up to the midterms, fearmongering about transgender issues is becoming an obsession on the right.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo

item.title: “The Rings of Power” on Amazon Can’t Do J.R.R. Tolkien Justice
item.description: Amazon’s “The Rings of Power” will struggle to recreate the magic of Middle-earth, a world not fit for “cinematic universe” treatment.
item.dc:creator: Michael D.C. Drout
item.category: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power (TV Program)
item.media:description: Morfydd Clark in Amazon Studios’ “The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power.” Not all stories are suited to being expanded and exploited by Hollywood.

item.title: Your Thursday Evening Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Cullen
item.media:description: President Biden is visiting Pennsylvania for the second time this week for his speech tonight.

item.title: What Is a ‘Fake’ Artist in 2022?
item.description: Firestorms over the “virtual rapper” FN Meka and faceless artists on Spotify have sparked conversations about alienation and creative agency.

item.title: How Gorbachev Changed the World
item.description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev set out to reform the Soviet Union. But the social and economic forces he unleashed ended up destroying it.
item.dc:creator: Sabrina Tavernise, Will Reid, Jessica Cheung, Michael Simon Johnson, Stella Tan, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
item.media:description: Mr. Gorbachev’s leadership ushered in the end of the Cold War and transformed the map of Europe, changing the world. It is a world that Mr. Putin is now at war against.

item.title: “中国特供版”电影和美国的“觉醒文化”是一回事吗？
item.description: 《小黄人2》中国上映版本结局被改引发争议，有中国网友指出，美国同样存在对文艺作品的审查。真的如此吗？美国文艺界对经典作品的重新审视和反思究竟是怎么一回事？
item.dc:creator: Rong Xiaoqing

item.title: In a Japanese Nursing Home, Some Workers Are Babies
item.description: They get paid in formula and diapers, and their work hours are flexible, in a program that connects people across generations and brightens lives.
item.dc:creator: Hikari Hida and John Yoon

item.title: Biden’s Student Loan Plan Could Face a Protracted Legal Fight
item.description: The White House’s use of emergency powers to enact widespread debt relief could be ripe for challenges.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden’s announcement to cancel some student loan debt fulfills a campaign promise to help graduates who are drowning in debt at a time of surging education costs.

item.title: Want to Buy a Banksy? This Building Comes With It.
item.description: The painting, known as “Swing Girl” and “Girl on a Swing,” and the building it adorns are headed to the auction block with the hope that the sale price will reach $30 million.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin
item.media:credit: Beth Coller for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tarina Tarantino and Alfonso Campos paid $4 million for a downtown Los Angeles building in 2007. They hope the building, now adorned with a mural by Banksy, will get $30 million at auction.

item.title: Teenagers Died of Asphyxiation in South Africa Tavern, Parents Are Told
item.description: Health officials met with families that had waited more than two months to learn why 21 teenagers died one June night in an overcrowded bar.
item.dc:creator: Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: The entrance to Enyobeni Tavern in Scenery Park, East London, South Africa. The deaths of the 21 teenagers have been called a national tragedy.

item.title: How Love Languages Became a Cultural Phenomenon
item.description: The author of the seminal book on love languages is surprised that the concept has become a cultural phenomenon. But he still wants couples to heed his advice.
item.dc:creator: Alisha Haridasani Gupta and Luis Mazón
item.media:description: Karolyn and Gary Chapman at their wedding reception in August 1961. The couple, who have been married for over 60 years, said they had a rocky start.

item.title: My Marriage Has a Third Wheel: Our Child
item.description: An only child can make the relationship between Mom and Dad uniquely complicated.
item.dc:creator: Jancee Dunn

item.title: How to Spot a Love Addict
item.description: Experts question whether we can describe a toxic relationship the way we talk about gambling or alcohol. But some have found that framework to be a helpful step in the road to freedom.
item.dc:creator: Kaila Yu

item.title: Dealing With Interfering Grandparents
item.description: How to navigate a challenging relationship.
item.dc:creator: Carla Bruce-Eddings

item.title: Sometimes I Hate My Husband’s Peloton
item.description: Yes, exercise is hugely beneficial. But can too much of a good thing cause tension in your relationship?
item.dc:creator: Holly Burns

item.title: What Does a Dancing Body Feel Like in Ukraine? ‘I Am a Gun.’
item.description: The country’s experimental dance artists, independent and resilient, are using their skills in a new arena: war.
item.dc:creator: Gia Kourlas
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Krystyna Shyshkarova, who has a dance school in Kyiv, is developing a system that she calls “tactical choreography,” which combines modern dance techniques and tactical training.
